content: Removed extra line at end of validator 2.
Added "write answer" to stub generator.

I edited: # is NOT a hashtag but a number sign.
According to gucharmap:

    #
    U+0023 NUMBER SIGN

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear description, fun subject, just the right kind of difficulty for the easy category. Really nice !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Well designed easy puzzle

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The problem is fun and easy but challenging. The theme is original and the description is engaging.

Tests and solution look good to me.

Nice work!

You should use word as variable instead of letters. It would make the stub more useful.

L -> number_of rooms
F -> rooms
N -> number_of_crewmates
K -> records_length
crewmate -> record
Very cool (and funny)
Cool topic!

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Imho, the statement is a bit too long/verbose for a CoC. Maybe this can be simplified?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The idea of working on Among Us is original in itself even if it's still work on a String.
You listened well and corrected the errors
I approve
I love the idea and execution of the problem. I think it might be a bit more thematic and consistent if you use question marks instead of hashtags, but other than that, I love it!
I love the idea and execution of the problem. I think it might be a bit more thematic and consistent if you use question marks instead of hashtags, but other than that, I love it!
AMOGUS

Nice puzzle :) easy enough, but not trivial at all

As UnicornP said, formatting with {{}}, [[]], ``, and <<>> would be useful.

There are a few mistakes in the Input/output section: "sepErated" should be "sepArated"; you mixed up the meaning of N and K; the restriction on input strings containing only ABCDEF# is not correct.
I'd suggest these fixes:
----------------------------------
Input
An integer, L.
A line F of length L, corresponding to the room layout. All characters in F will be uppercase and unique.
2 space separated integers, N and K, representing the number of crewmates and the length of time the crewmates were recorded (length of each string).
This is followed by N strings, comprised of capital letters and/or hashtags (#). It is guaranteed that any capital letters will be present in string F.
Output
N lines corresponding to each of the N crewmates. Output "SUS" if the crewmate is suspicious, otherwise print "NOT SUS".
--------------------

With the updated texts, I will gladly approve ;)

In the Input section, you say that the K strings are comprised of capital letters from A to F or hashtag. Shouldn’t it be the letters found in the second line of the input?
Also, the last validator has a number of rooms higher than all the test cases, which may cause an error difficult to fix if the solution is not optimized enough.

> For input AFEBAFE, the path the crewmate took is A->F->E->B->A->F->E. This is sus because a normal crewmate cannot travel to room B from room F in 1 minute.

I don't see that the crewmate does travel from B to F in this input. Should it be that a normal crewmate cannot travel from E to B?

Many notes:

» You should keep the same number of crewmates in Validator #1 as in Test case #1.

» Since you have a giant wall of text, I highly recommend taking time to add {{}}, [[]], ``, and <<>> to format and make your prompt look pretty.

» The only time we see a full ### string is in validator #1... which is to say, we don't see it. I would introduce a full ### in test case #2, and add a ### to the Big Data Test.

» Also, consider adding two more test cases before The Big Data test that has a lot of rooms but not that many crewmates, and vice versa. I see no reason why L cannot be as low as 4, theoretically.

» I haven't played Among Us yet D: but it's easy to understand the statement, and it's fun to read. Good job!

Notes:
- Certain validators are basically the test cases, but swapped order. This should be enough to prevent case-by-case shenanigans. However, any such attempt would be foiled by case 4. I wrote a test case generator for case #4, so those are the only cases I'm really willing to redo - the other 3 are made by hand, so it's a bit tedious to make.
- Full strings of hashtags are valid as you can't observe any "venting".
- Regarding issues with true/false style output: That's why the lower bound on N is 5. The probability of guessing all of them is extremely slim.
- LMAO

I've updated validator 1 to match test case 1. I think the number of crewmates shouldn't affect it too much, however validator 1 had too many hashtag test cases compared to test 1. I removed all the hashtags from both.
I've added a full ### string in test 2, thanks for pointing that out. I might make more cases later.
I wasn't sure how formatting works - I tried using markdown-style syntax, which didn't seem to work. I'll try using the formatting options you outlined later.
Thanks for the feedback!
You are correct, this path is sus because of the minimum distance from E to B, not F to B. Good catch!

Input specifications are fixed :)

I don't believe people should be having TLE errors with this problem. The validator is also within the given input specifications, so I do not believe it to be an issue.
Fixed :)

:rofl: 
maybe ... but it is a puzzle , not a CoC

Input specifications for coding problems do not follow code variable naming conventions - they are entirely different things. Using long names increases bloat in these statements and makes it more confusing. The stub already gives sufficient detail as is, your suggested variable names would make the statement way too verbose. Suggestion declined.

You still have a mixup with the meanings of N and K in your input and output description.

Apart of that this puzzle is a nice one; would also approve if the mistakes would be fixed :3

I've adjusted the input/output description. I think I've fixed everything by now, but if there's anything else, feel free to leave a comment. Thanks everyone for pointing out things I've missed, it helps a ton :)
While editing, click the question mark next to Statement, description, Constraints, etc., and it will pop up with a guide to the formatting options.
